5.text:
Several people have mailed me recently, sharing
that they're questioning their own religious beliefs.

9.text:
Some are feeling hollow, some are frustrated,
some are feeling fearful and isolated.

14.text:
Others are feeling cold and logical,
approaching things analytically.

18.text:
Reading their different stories, I'm prompted to share
my own transition to atheism with them

24.text:
taking into account both the emotional
and the cognitive components of that switch.

29.text:
So here are two videos, each addressing
one of those aspects

32.text:
and using psychological models as frameworks
to contextualise the psychological events involved.

37.text:
In this video I'm going to explore the cognitive
side of my transition from christian to atheist,

41.text:
using a concept from person-centered theory
called congruence.

45.text:
In person-centered theory, the self is sometimes
represented in two components:

52.text:
Experience refers to the bald data
we gather through our five senses,

56.text: and from internal and visceral sensations.

58.text:
Now there's clearly a bewildering volume
of data available to the senses.

62.text: Person-centered theory suggests we have to find ways of processing this data

65.text: into manageable, meaningful chunks and patterns

68.text: — and that we do this through our self-structure.

71.text:
This term refers the mechanisms we use
to categorise and organise our experiences,

75.text:
to give our world structure — drawing on beliefs,
associations, values, and reasoning.

79.text:
For simplicity, in this video I'm going
to call this component 'beliefs'.

83.text:
Person-centered theory suggests that we instinctively
strive to understand the world

87.text:
to integrate our beliefs about the world
with our sensory experience of it.

91.text: And this overlapping area is called 'congruence'.

94.text:
A lot of our early organisation of the world
comes through naming experiences in the world:

101.text:
Lots of these are essentially neutral.
Others will take on emotional associations.

106.text:
When we get burned by fire
our senses register pain.

109.text:
But not all associations are based
on our own experience.

111.text:
As a child I learned, for instance, that some parts
of the human body were 'rude', even 'bad'.

117.text: Did my senses tell me this? No. Other people did.

120.text:
But why would I take on other people's meanings
and definitions, when it's not my own experience?

124.text:
Person-centered theory uses the term 'conditions
of worth' to describe the environment in which

129.text:
the child learns the behaviours and attitudes
that get rewarded with approval and love,

133.text:
and the ones that will be punished
with disapproval and rejection.

136.text: To fit in, and maintain the approval so essential to its survival,

139.text: the child takes on the views of its guardians,

142.text: not just as opinions but as absolute truths.

145.text: In doing so the child moves away from its own authentic, congruent experience.

149.text: And as the child moves out of congruence,

152.text: mismatches arise between experience and belief.

154.text:
Person-centered theory describes
two kinds of mismatch:

159.text:
These are probably best
demonstrated with stereotypes.

162.text: John's been taught that 'all gay men are effeminate'.

165.text:
This isn't based on reality. But it will now dictate
his mental reality in the following way.

170.text:
Only effeminate men will
get through that stereotype filter.

173.text:
John has no concept for masculine gay men,
so when they come along,

176.text:
he simply fails to register them in his awareness.
This is denial.

180.text:
But what if a masculine man
openly announces he's gay?

183.text:
This is a more direct challenge
to John's stereotype — one he can't ignore

187.text:
— so instead he twists reality to fit the
stereotype. This is distortion.

191.text:
Hence, John's false stereotype
continues to feel true to him.

196.text:
How does all this relate to my religious upbringing
and conversion to atheism?

200.text:
As a child I was taught god existed. I accepted
it as truth because others told me it was true.

205.text:
It wasn't based on any kind of reality
accessible to my own senses.

208.text: But it created filters, just like John's gay stereotype

212.text:
that would then profoundly affect
what information I was able to let in.

215.text:
Solid scientific facts that conflicted with my belief
were now denied .... or distorted.

221.text:
People were distorted.
I was distorted.

227.text:
As this distorted framework of belief was built up,
I learned to hold incredible dissonances in my head,

232.text:
so that human morality was completely
flipped on its head when it came to god,

236.text:
who performed the most appalling acts, punishing all
humankind for the sins of two individuals,

241.text:
drowning the entire population of the planet
except for Noah and the contents of his ark,

245.text: condemning his children to eternal torture in hell.

248.text:
It all made sense. And even where it hadn't,
I'd learned very early on that it was wrong to say so.

254.text:
This dangerous-sounding word 'blasphemy' would
be used if I did, and would instantly stop all discussion.

259.text:
Ironically, what loosened the grip of these
non-indigenous beliefs I was defending,

263.text: was when I first attempted to prove them.

265.text:
A religious education teacher had challenged me
to explain why I believed what I believed.

270.text:
I talk about thisexperience at greater length
in the accompanying video — 'transition to atheism'.

274.text:
But basically
when I couldn't come up with any good answers,

277.text: I asked the other christians in my life.

279.text: I knew the answers had to be good

280.text:
and that 'god moves in mysterious ways' and other such
ideas weren't going to impress my teacher,

285.text:
so — for the first time — I pressed
a lot harder with my questions,

289.text: and was far more discriminating about the answers.

291.text:
I was convinced my fellow christians
would be able to supply the answers.

294.text: And I was stunned to find they couldn't.

297.text:
Having never experienced god myself, my entire
belief hinged on the fact that other people had.

303.text:
But suddenly I saw how easy it was to explain away
the things they were giving as proof of god.

307.text: Things like a sick person getting better after prayer.

310.text:
Well, some sick people get better. Some don't.
What about the ones who don't?

314.text: 'It's just their time to go to heaven.'

316.text:
So for people who do get better, it's not
their time to go to heaven? 'That's right.'

320.text:
So, if it's already predetermined whether
it's your time or not, why pray at all?

324.text:
And why claim it was prayer that made them better?
'Er ....'

328.text:
The critical thinking I permitted myself, in order to get
the most convincing defences of christianity I could

333.text: allowed me instead to see the truth.

334.text:
That I was just following people,
who were following other people,

337.text:
who were following other people,
and so on until who knew when.

341.text:
None of us trusting in our own
authentic sensory experience,

345.text:
but instead trusting in the distortions
implanted in us as children.

349.text:
As my distortions collapsed,
I was able to let reality in.

352.text:
I was able to see that it's never wrong to
demand good solid answers

355.text: to questions about anything you're asked to believe.

358.text:
And if the responses to those good solid questions
are threatening or dissuading in any way,

363.text: something's wrong — and we should ask ourselves:

365.text:
'What's so fragile that it can't stand up to sustained
scrutiny, and needs threats to protect it?'

370.text: Which seems the more likely candidate to you?

372.text:
I was able to see that the concept of hell
is a child's concept of punishment —

377.text:
that child-like fear of all-engulfing unimaginable
consequences for doing something wrong.

382.text:
When we grow up, we realise parents aren't actually
into inflicting

386.text:
unimaginable consequences
on their children — for anything.

388.text: And if someone does want to torture their children?

391.text: We call them a psychopath. End of.

393.text:
It's perhaps religion's greatest coup that
it's managed to drive such an efficient wedge

398.text: between a person's own senses and their beliefs.

401.text: Since my shift back to greater congruence

403.text:
— I've had many theists and supernaturalists
approach to challenge me,

407.text:
each with their distinct brand of beliefs, but all so far
with one standout aspect in common:

412.text:
The requirement that I deny
my own authentic experience.

416.text:
This is in sharp contrast to science,
which has no need to do this,

420.text: In fact, it encourages the opposite.

422.text:
It values the accessibility of information to everyone
to investigate for themselves, using their own senses.

428.text:
I actually have no inherent loyalty to the
idea of there being a god or not being a god.

433.text:
God suddenly pops up, makes an appearance
— then, believe me, I'll believe.

436.text:
My loyalty is to reality, to reliable evidence, to what
is available, through whatever means, to my senses.

443.text: That's what makes me an atheist — nothing else.

446.text: Yes I know all the stereotypes — all atheists are anti-god, anti-society, rebellious, immoral.

453.text: And I believe I've covered stereotypes already.

455.text: My atheism is purely about a demand for evidence.

458.text: And those who scorn demands for evidence, by the way

460.text:
— who scorn 'scepticism' — are being
completely disingenuous.

464.text:
If someone came along claiming
to be the second coming,

467.text:
is anyone out there really trying
to say they'd just uncritically accept that?

471.text: They wouldn't be at all .... sceptical?

473.text:
I find it hilarious just how fanatically sceptical
some anti-sceptics get

478.text:
in trying to tear down the solid science
that opposes their supernatural beliefs.

482.text: We all demand evidence. And that's a good thing.

485.text:
Reliable evidence is where the circles meet.
Evidence could be seen as a congruence generator.

490.text: But not when it's split like this.

492.text:
We all demand evidence for things we find
hard to believe. Let's go one step further.

497.text:
Demand evidence for the things
we find easy to believe.

500.text:
And let's pass on to our children
the very best of our knowledge —

503.text: not the very worst of our unexamined dogmas.
